item.description:

  • City: REDDING
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics notified ERTS of a cargo release at terminal URD. It was reported that an unknown quantity of Nitrous Oxide (UN1070) was released from at least 1 cylinder due to improper loading; when the strap was released, it hit one of the valves. The release impacted the inside of the trailer immediately but was quickly moved into the yard. Terminal personnel advised they would allow the cylinder to bleed out. No waste was generated.

  • Description: During off loading it was discovered that the load had shifted during transit and that the one 55 metal drum of Magni Performance Covered Paint (UN1263) had been damaged by a sharp object and had released 1 quart of product. The warehouse crew was able to contain and cleanup thew release, so no contractors were dispatched.

item.title: Report X-2023120515
item.description:
Report X-2023120515

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-15T21:09:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-08
  • City: FORT SMITH
  • State: AR
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: A FSMA spill agent was called to the sort input for a fiberboard box with signs of a release. The spill agent was told that the fiberboard box was dropped during the unloading process. While investigating the shipment the agent observed that the source of the release came from between the release valve and the cylinder. The fire extinguisher was packaged with molded styrofoam on top and bottom inside of the fiberboard box. All contents were released from the extinguisher and gauge of the release valve reads as empty. All contents were placed into a steel salvage package.

The fiberboard box contained a steel drum inside and the cap on top of the drum was loose. All contents were placed into a steel salvage package. A new declaration will be obtained for movement.

item.title: Report X-2023120507
item.description:
Report X-2023120507

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-15T21:09:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-07
  • City: MEMPHIS
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDERAL EXPRESS CORPORATION
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The shipment was discovered during sort operations. A metal can inside of the box leaked liquid that was bubbling, steaming and had corroded away a large portion of the metal can. PH litmus test resulted as strong acid (1). Contents also included a paint brush, a steel brush, and 2 rotary brushes. The metal can was unidentifiable due to the level of corrosion. The contents were neutralized with baking soda and placed into a Steel Salvage Package. The customer was contacted and advised that the shipment contained Pickling Paste. The shipment is being held for FAA investigation.

item.title: Report E-2023120137
item.description:
Report E-2023120137

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-15T21:09:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-08
  • City: ROCK ISLAND
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XQC experienced a UN1760 Gunsmoke release from a box containing (2) 2.5-gallon poly jugs. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 2.5-gallons of material released from one of the jugs due to a forklift puncture. Absorbents and pH Up neutralizer were utilized to clean and neutralize the release. The empty damaged drum, impacted absorbents, PPE, and impacted cardboard were containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023120133
item.description:
Report E-2023120133

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-15T21:09:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-08
  • City: LAREDO
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal LLA experienced a UN1866 ELAN-Cast P 300 S RTC Low Odor release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 50-gallons of material released to the entire trailer floor as well as a 30’ x 20’ area of the concrete lot below due to the trailer wall puncturing the tote. The puncture was patched with wood to stop the release and the material was transferred into a new tote for shipment on. The free-standing liquid material was collected with a drum vac into (2) 55-gallon metal drums. Floor dry was then deployed and worked into the impacted areas and then collected into a third 55-gallon metal drum. The punctured tote was patched with absorbent pads & chemical tape. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

item.title: Report E-2023120131
item.description:
Report E-2023120131

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-06
  • City: COMMERCE
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: ROADRUNNER TRANSPORTATION SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: on 12/7/2023-Roadrunner notified ERTS that there are 3 -11 gallon metal pails containing paint UN1263, Paint, Class 3, PGII that were discovered to be leaking the in the rear of a freight trailer. It was reported that the release was reportedly caused due to other freight being stacked on the pails. Roadrunner advised that most the released paint had already dried and terminal personnel conducted the cleanup and overpacking operations for the damaged freight and freight trailer. The release was contained to the freight trailer and no soils, drains or waterways were impacted by the release. All generated waste was staged on site for pending disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023120111
item.description:
Report E-2023120111

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-15T21:09:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-07
  • City: PORT ALLEN
  • State: LA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: While unloading a pallet of waste from a trailer at Veolia's ten day intransit facility, a Veolia employee heard a pop and realized the forks on the forklift were protruding out of the back of the pallet and punctured a 15 gallon 1H1 drum of flammable liquid located on the pallet behind the one he was moving. Approximately 100 ml of the material leaked out before the hole closed on itself. The employee moved the forklift away from the area and shut it off, then proceeded to contain the spill with absorbent. The employee and the Veolia site manager then donned correct PPE and promptly overpacked the container and cleaned up the spill area.

  • Description: On 12/5/2023 at approximately 1326, Dangerous Goods Administration received a call from Employee 5190395 at the staion location in Miami, reporting an hazardous spill . The shipment consists of a one fiberboard box classified as UN 3373, in which the inner container leaked due to a loose screw-on top. The shipment suffered total loss and the shipper has been notified. In compliance with 49 CFR 171.15, this incident was reported to the National Response Center and filed under report # 1385950.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: At 5am, a package handler brought over a hazmat suspected of leaking to the QA area from the unload area. The package handler found it upside down in the trailer. Once it was brought to QA, we segregated it from other packages to prevent further damage to other packages. DescribePack: Package was found upside down. Wet spot is on top of the box, which is consistent with a package being upside down. Cap was only slightly loose on the jug that leaked. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was segregated from other packages and people to minimize risk of damage to packages, and harm to workers.

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package handler picked package up by the handles, which ripped due to the weight of the box. The uneven weight caused her to partially drop the package and carried it to the trailer on its side. Package handler was notified that the package was leaking and she put it down and the damage was called out for immediate cleanup and processing. DescribePack: Caps were loose and it was noted that the bottles were packed pretty tightly inside with no inner partitions/separations. When the bottles were removed from the box, the sound of air hissing out from the caps was heard due to them being pressed together tightly. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was put into a spill liner/tote and taken away to be processed and spillage was cleaned up with spill absorbent.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: 1. X-2023120482 SequenceEvent: WHILE THE PACKAGE HANDLER WAS UNLOADING THE TRAILER, THEY NOTICED THIS PACKAGE WAS LEAKING AND MOVED IT TO THE END OF THE TRAILER AND NOTIFIED THEIR MANAGER. THE MANAGER QUICKLY INFORMED QA OF THE SITUATION AND QA GRABBED A TOTE LINED WITH A CLEAR HAZMAT BAG, FOLD ABSORB AND NEUTRALIZER. THEY RUSHED OVER TO THE AREA AND PLACED THE PACKAGE IN THE TOTE. QA CLEANED UP THE AREA WITH THE FOLD ABSORB. ONCE IT WAS SAFE, THEY BROUGHT THE PACKAGE BACK TO QA AND PLACED IN THE HAZMAT PROCESSING CAGE. DescribePack: THE PACKAGE WAS LOADED ON ITS SIDE AND CAUSED ONE OF THE CONTAINERS TO LEAK OUT THRU THE CAP. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: THE PACKAGE WAS PLACED IN A TOTE WITH A LINED HAZMAT BAG AND CLEANED UP WITH FOLD ABSORB. 2. X-2023120485 SequenceEvent: WHILE QA WAS CLEANING UP A SPILL, THEY NOTICED THIS WAS ALSO IN THE SAME TRAILER AND WAS WET. THEY PLACED THE PACKAGE IN A TOTE AND CLEANED UP THE AREA WITH FOLD ABSORB. ONCE IT WAS SAFE, THEY BROUGHT THE PACKAGE BACK TO THE QA AREA AND PLACED IN THE HAZMAT PROCESSING CAGE. DescribePack: THE PACKAGE WAS LOADED ON ITS SIDE AND CAUSED THE CONTENTS TO LEAK OUT THRU ONE OF THE CAPS. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: THE PACKAGE WAS PLACED IN A TOTE WITH A LINED HAZMAT BAG AND CLEANED UP WITH FOLD ABSORB. 3. X-2023120488 SequenceEvent: WHILE THE PACKAGE HANDLER WAS PICKING OFF THE IC BELT, THEY NOTICED THIS PACKAGE WAS WET AND POSSIBLY LEAKING. THEY PLACED IT THE FLOOR AND INFORMED THE MANAGER. THE MANAGER QUICKLY INFORMED QA THE SITUATION THEY HAD. QA QUICKLY GRABBED A TOTE LINED WITH A CLEAR, LARGE HAZMAT BAG AND FOLD ABSORB. THEY RUSHED OVER TO THE AREA. THEY NOTICED THE PACKAGE WAS AN OXIDIZER AND PLACED IN THE TOTE. QA MADE SURE THE AREA WAS SAFE AND SECURE. THEY BROUGHT THE PACKAGE BACK TO QA AND PLACED IN THE HAZMAT PROCESSING CAGE. DescribePack: THE PACKAGE WAS LOADED ON ITS SIDE AND CAUSED ONE OF THE CONTAINERS TO LEAK OUT THRU THE CAP. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: THE PACKAGE WAS PLACED IN A TOTE AND CLEANED UP WITH FOLD ABSORB.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Driver alerted Quality Assurance staff that a hazmat package seemed to be giving off a strong smell but there did not appear to be a leak of any kind. Package was brought to QA for inspection. No visible damage to the contents inside or to the outer box. No visible liquid stains on the box indicating any kind of leakage. Just a very strong smell of the contents. DescribePack: No visible holes or areas of the container appear to be leaking. Can was tipped in multiple positions to see if there was a leak spot. Found nothing. Just a strong smell from the metal can. Can was place in the box inside of 3 plastic bags. Padded absorbent was placed inside the bags to act as a wedge to hold the can in place. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Package was pulled from the van and dock area and taken to QA for inspection and then placed in the vented hazardous materials area.

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal XRC experienced a UN2922 Thiocare H101 71% release from a 330-gallon poly tote. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 4-gallons of product released to a 16’ x 18.5’ area of the trailer floor due to a crack in the tote lid. The material was transferred from the damaged tote into a new one. Spill-X-A was utilized to neutralize the impacted area. The damaged tote was cut up and containerized along with all impacted rags and PPE into (3) 55-gallon poly drums. The waste was staged onsite for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Description: While in transit, (2) 55DF's containing Sulfuric Acid 1.500 (UN1830) fell over as a result of inadequate preparation for transportation forcing the bung caps to loosen and release 20-gallons of product on the pallet, the trailer floor, and the asphalt beneath the trailer. Contractors neutralized the release using sodium bicarbonate and solidified the liquid with oil dry. The impacted pallet was cut-up and containerized with the rest of the spill debris into (3) 55DF's for waste disposal. No storm drains, water ways, or soil were impacted by the release.

  • Incident Date: 2023-12-02
  • City: HOUSTON
  • State: TX
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS FREIGHT, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: While in transit, (1) box containing (2) 1-gallon bottles of Blue Whale Muriatic Acid (UN1789) became crushed as a result of inadequate preparation for transportation. During the off-loading process, the damaged, crushed product began leaking onto the concrete dock floor; a total amount of 1-gallon. A Contractor neutralized the release using Kolorsafe Liquid Acid Neutralizer before absorbing the liquid and containerizing the spill debris into the proper UN-rated shipping container (a vented 55-gallon fiber drum). Additionally, the pallet in which the load was shipped on was also cut-up and containerized for waste disposal. Lastly, the impacted box that the leaking bottles shipped in was neutralized and containerized for waste disposal. No storm drains, waterways, or soil were impacting by the release.

  • City: COLUMBUS

  • Carrier/Reporter: Fedex Ground Package System, Inc.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 1
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: SequenceEvent: The corrosive HazMat was shipped to the facility in the belly of the trailer. According to the injured employee, the HazMat was leaking in transit. They went to lift the HazMat package and found the contents of the package had been spilled onto their clothes when it made contact with their abdomen. There was no sign of a spill prior to the employee lifting the package. DescribePack: The package contained two plastic containers of corrosive liquid. One of the containers were found with a missing cap/lid. The containers hold approximately 2.5 gallons of liquid. The spilled container looked to be missing around half of its contents. DurationRel: 6 and MitigateEffect: Employee used a shower station to mitigate injury to their skin. The manager of the unload stopped work and had QA assess and clean the spill.

item.description:

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-30
  • City: WEST LAFAYETTE
  • State: IN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: CLEAN HARBORS ENVIRONMENTAL SERVICES, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: During transportation a passenger vehicle flagged the driver down. The driver pulled over and he was notified that there was a spray coming from the trailer. the driver inspected the trailer again and found that a cleanout cap was missing from the top of the trailer. The spray had gotten on the passenger vehicle. The local county Sherriff reported to the scene. The liquid that was released was evaporating very quickly and no residue was collecting on the ground. We had a response team show up to the scene they were able to bring a new cap for the cleanout and the driver was on his way. The driver of the personal vehicle later reported that her and her child was exposed to the material because there window was down when they were behind our vehicle and that they went to there physician and was told to go to the ER. I have not been able to get an update on the visit to the ER.

item.title: Report E-2023120129
item.description:
Report E-2023120129

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-15T21:09:53+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-30
  • City: MELROSE PARK
  • State: IL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: R & L CARRIERS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On November 30, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of UN1263 was crushed in transit and released approximately two and a half (2.5) gallons of product to the trailer interior. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from HazChem Environmental (HCE) to remediate the impacted site. HCE personnel removed one (1) damaged and leaking 5-gallon pail from the load, and they wiped down any impacted pails with absorbent pads. The remediated pails were restacked and rewrapped for further shipment and processing. All spent absorbent pads and the one (1) damaged 5-gallon pail were collected and containerized into one (1) 55-gallon drum that was labeled as hazardous and staged in the terminal's waste holding room.

  • City: SCHENECTADY

  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 11/08/2023, a Veolia employee from the Schenectady, NY office was unloading drums from a truck into another trailer at the Veolia, Schenectady, NY 10 day intransit facility when the employee noticed that a drum was leaking from the gasket of the lid of the 551A2 drum. The faulty gasket allowed for mineral oil to leak out of the drum. The mineral oil was used to coat the reactive lithium in the drum. No actual lithium was released from the drum. The 551A2 lid was opened and the gasket of the drum was inspected and found to be defective and had allowed mineral oil to seep out. The gasket on the drum was replaced and the entire drum was overpacked into an 85 gallon 1A2 salvage drum. Transportation to the ultimate disposal facility was continued.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: Package was found near door 150 on the other side of the load 1 belt. Package was outside of its box sitting inside a plastic bag. The box was upside down. Upon investigation it was determined that the plastic bag had a tear in it and had leaked out some of the contents. Item was a white powder and the box had Fully Regulated HazMat labeling. Package was immediately taken off the warehouse floor and isolated from the rest of the staff. DescribePack: The plastic bag did not have a seal on it of any kind. This kept the plastic bag inside open, which caused a leak. There was also a small hole on the bottom of the bag. This caused leakage from two separate areas. DurationRel: 0 and MitigateEffect: Package was taken to the HazMat Cage for isolation and processing.

  • Description: On November 29, 2023, one (1) 330-gallon tote of hydrogen peroxide was damaged in transit and released approximately one (1) gallon of product to the trailer interior and pavement underneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Enhanced Environmental and Emergency (E3) to remediate the impacted site. E3 personnel transferred the virgin product into two (2) 275-gallon poly totes that were staged for further shipment. The crew then deployed granular absorbents to the released product in the trailer and on the pavement and swept them up with hand tools. All spent absorbents, the damaged and empty tote, and any cleanup debris were collected and containerized into one (1) vented 55-gallon poly drum.

Approximately 3-5 cups was released onto the floor of the truck. The handler immediately grabbed absorbent material to contain the spill. The in house response team then dawned the proper PPE and began to clean up the material and overpack the damaged drum and dispose of the absorbent material in the appropriate manor. The event only lasted 15-30 minutes start to finish.

item.title: Report E-2023120071
item.description:
Report E-2023120071

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-14T21:11:20+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-29
  • City: JAMAICA
  • State: NY
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: LUFTHANSA CARGO AKTIENGESELLSCHAFT
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 2201 this evening we were contacted by Export Dock agent Jorge Lazo that LH6751S/29 ex PHL came in with a DG spill. When the truck was opened there was liquid already spilled and shutters were closed immediately. We immediately cordoned off the area and called PAPD to report the DG spill. PAPD Officer Farber (Badge#1829) responded at 2220 to investigate. PAPD ESU & Port Auth Ops arrived shortly after. Hassan simultaneously contacted the 24HR emergency contact on DGD (Celinia @ NCEC) and was advised safety precautions, spill response and containment methods. This was relayed to Port Ops and PAPD ESU. PAPD started containment process with speedy dry at 2235 and completed at 2320. 7 of 36 Jerricans (AWB 020-69236160) were affected and stored in containment drums in the DG reject area. AWB: 020-43064475 was loaded next to leaking jerricans and was also wet/stored in containment drum. We also noticed that liquid had leaked from trailer to tire and ground. Speedy dry was used to contain the leak. Safety-Kleen was contacted at 2323 for cleanup of contained spill and disposal. Safety-Kleen dispatched a response team at 0105 Trailer is currently in Bay 52. Driver is onsite waiting on cleanup to leave. IQSMS Report: 15387 PAPD Case: 23K302528 Truck number: 6751S/29NOV Driver name: Jose Deleon Provider: Forward Air Rcvd with Seal number 126350982 ex PHL. Shipment packed in non UN specification package.

  • Description: Enviroserve was dispatched to the site. Upon the contractor’s arrival, personnel observed that the released material impacted a 10ft-by-30ft area of the asphalt/concrete parking lot, the trailer floor and concrete dock floor and estimated that ten (10) gallons of material was released due to forklift damaging one (1) 275-gallon poly tote. Enviroserve personnel gravity transferred the remaining product to a new poly tote and the damaged tote was cut-up and placed into one 55-gallon poly drum. The new 275-gallon poly tote was shipped on to the consignee. Enviroserve personnel deployed a neutralizer to the impacted areas and then used a granular absorbent to gather the spent material. The recovered material was containerized into one (1) additional 55-gallon poly drum. The generated waste was staged onsite at the terminal in a secure location prior to the contractor demobilization. The generated waste will remain onsite for the ESTES DGRM team to coordinate disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023120039
item.description:
Report E-2023120039

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-14T21:11:20+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-09
  • City: HENDERSON
  • State: CO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: VEOLIA ES TECHNICAL SOLUTIONS, L.L.C.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On November 9, 2023 a trailer in temporary storage at Veolia's 10 day intransit facility in Henderson Colorado was observed to be smoking. The dock area was immediately evacuated and the Veolia emergency response team evaluated the situation. Further investigation revealed a 55 gallon drum containing inner containers of hydrochloric acid and alkyl sulfonic acid was improperly packed. The container of sulfonic acid shifted and fell on its side during transportation resulting in a release of material which mixed with the hydrochloric acid causing a reaction and vapor release. The Veolia ER team repacked the material into two separate containers - one containing the hydrochloric acid and one containing only the alkyl sulfonic acid. The alkyl sulfonic acid drum was reloaded on the rear of the vehicle for continued transportation to the disposal facility.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On November 22, 2023, two (2) 3.5 liter cans of UN1866 were crushed in transit and released approximately less than one (<1) gallon of product to the product boxes. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Lone Star Hazmat (LSH) to remediate the impacted site. LSH personnel placed the two (2) damaged cans of UN1866 into one (1) 5-gallon pail. The impacted boxes were placed into one (1) additional 5-gallon pail. All containers were staged onsite for future disposal.

item.title: Report E-2023120015
item.description:
Report E-2023120015

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-14T21:11:20+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-16
  • City: MAGNOLIA
  • State: MS
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: XPO LOGISTICS, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On November 16, 2023, at 0830 ET, XPO Logistics Terminal LJS experienced an over the road diesel fuel and hazardous cargo release due to a single vehicle rollover accident. The unit left the roadway resulting in a release to the shoulder soil. On November 16, 2023, at 0935 ET, XPO Logistics retained ERTS to manage and oversee the incident. ERTS dispatched ES&H to the site to perform all cleanup and remediation activities. On November 16, 2023, at 1230 ET, ES&H personnel arrived on site and began assisting the onsite wrecker company, Lewis Wrecker Service, with clearing the wreckage debris. The wrecker company hauled the two damaged trailers offsite after conducting a soil/debris scrape to remove as much material and debris from the ground. ES&H personnel were able to confirm approximately 25-gallon of diesel released from a damaged saddle tank along with approximately 100-gallons of UN1210 STR Steam Mat from (2) 55-gallon metal drums, and approximately 1- quart of UN3077 Cyasorb THT 7001 EF Light Stabilizer (PGIII) from a single 50-pound poly bag. The impacted soil area was confirmed to measure approximately 20’ x 30’. The contractors confirmed the majority of the cargo released to the inner trailer and freight. A roll off was utilized to containerize (20) 55-gallon metal drums of STR Steam Mat that were not releasing, along with two empty drums of this product. A total of (60) 50-pound bags of Cyasorb were individually poly wrapped and placed in the roll off. A total of (6) 5-gallon poly jugs of non-regulated PureOil Formulation K were placed into the roll off. One 55-gallon poly drum of debris, impacted grass, and soil was also generated and staged in the roll off. The roll off was then hauled to the wrecker yard. On November 17, 2023, ES&H personnel returned to the site to assess the area and complete final cleanup. ES&H located a small indent in the ground measuring 4' x 18" that was still impacted by some free-standing liquid of UN1210 STR Steam Mat. ES&H solidified the material with acid gator and collected it into their poly waste bags. Acid gator was deployed near the tree as well. An additional 17 bags of impacted mud, dirt, leaves, and acid gator were generated and removed from site. The bags were hauled to the roll off and placed inside pending overpacking. On November 20, 2023, ES&H personnel returned to the wrecker yard for waste containerizing. The (20) 55-gallon drums of UN1210 STR Steam Mat were wiped down and shrink wrapped 4 to a pallet for salvage. The two empty drums of STR Steam Mat were crushed and containerized into a 55-gallon poly drum along with poly sheeting for disposal. All (60) 50-pound bags of UN3077 Cyasorb THT 7001 EF Light Stabilizer (PGIII) were containerized into 3 supersacks for disposal. The (6) 5-gallon poly jugs of PureOil Formulation K were poly wrapped to a pallet for disposal. All poly bags containing wreckage debris, mud, grass, soil, leaves, sticks, acid gator impacted with diesel & UN1210 were contain

  • Description: XPO Logistics terminal NNA experienced a customer location release of UN1203 Husqvarna 4-Stroke Fuel from 18 boxes each containing (4) 110-ounce metal cans. ERTS dispatched contractors to conduct cleanup operations. Contractors arrived onsite and confirmed approximately 1-gallon of product released to a 3’ x 3’ area of the pallet full of boxes of product. A total of 72 damaged cans and all impacted cardboard boxes were collected and containerized into (3) 55-gallon metal drums. The waste was transported to the XPO terminal located in Nashville, TN for terminal personnel to manage.

  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On November 22, 2023, one (1) 250-gallon tote of sodium hydroxide was forked and released approximately seventy (70) gallons of product to the loading dock. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Hull's Environmental Services (HES) to remediate the impacted site. HES personnel transferred the contents of the damaged tote into one (1) new 250-gallon tote. The crew then deployed granular absorbents to the release and worked them in using hand tools. All sodium hydroxide-impacted material was containerized in three (3) 55-gallon drums for onsite disposal.

  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On November 22, 2023, one (1) 5-gallon pail of adhesive was punctured and released approximately five (5) gallons of product to the trailer interior, pallet, and adjacent freight. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. TLE deployed granular absorbents to the release and worked them in using hand tools. The crew also utilized degreaser and absorbent wipes to further remediate the release. All adhesive-impacted material was containerized in one (1) 55-gallon drum for disposal by the facility.

  • Description: On November 22, 2023, one (1) 55-gallon drum of UN2693 was punctured by a forklift and released approximately fifty-five (55) gallons of product to the trailer interior and pavement underneath. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from First Call Environmental (FCE) to remediate the impacted site. FCE personnel utilized a pressure washer to the empty sodium bisulfite-impacted trailer and collected the impacted water with absorbents and absorbent pads. Crews collected and containerized the absorbents and absorbent pads into one (1) 55-gallon drum. All impacted pallets and cardboard were collected and containerized into three (3) 55-gallon drums and the damaged 55-gallon drum was placed into one (1) 95-gallon over-pack, all for terminal disposal.

item.title: Report X-2023111327
item.description:
Report X-2023111327

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-13T18:12:11+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-22
  • City: EARTH CITY
  • State: MO
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: UNITED PARCEL SERVICE
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: FULLY LABELED HAZ-MAT SHIPMENT WAS VISUALLY DISCOVERED WET IN APPEARANCE BY AN UNLOADER IN SECTION-E. WITHOUT TOUCHING THE PKG HE EVACUATED THE AREA AND NOTIFIED HIS IMMEDIATE SUPERVISOR. DMP WAS CONTACTED AND WITHIN 2 MINUTES A DESIGNATED RESPONDER ARRIVED WITH A FULLY STOCKED RESPONSE CART AND DONNING THE PROPER PPE. AFTER FOLLOWING THE DECISION TREE APPROPRIATE RESPONSE SHEET THE DAMAGE WAS CONTAINED (NO SPILLAGE OUTSIDE OF CARTON), THEN TRANSPORTED TO THE DMP PROCESSING AREA. CLOSER INSPECTION REVEALED THAT THE CAP ON 1 OF 4 POLY 1-GAL JUGS WAS LOOSE BY A FULL ROTATION, CAUSING APPROX. 16 OUNCES OF THE LIQUID TO LEAK THROUGH THE BREACH AND SATURATE THE SIDE WALL AND BASE OF THE CARTON. THERE WAS NO INTERNAL PACKING MATERIAL AND THE OUTER CARTON WAS A SINGLEWALL FIBERBOARD BOX, RATED AT A 44 LBS/IN EDGE CRUSH TEST (ECT).

  • Description: SequenceEvent: During sort package came down the line wet and leaking. Inspection identified that inner bottle of stain remover top came off which caused significant leak. Per SDS, product is a hazard material but outer Packaging has no Hazard markings . Package shipped as Undeclared DescribePack: Top of inner container came off at some point during shipping. As a result, container leaked entire content - destroying outer package. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: once damage identified, package separated from other sort packages and placed in a hazmat bag and bin for further processing.

item.title: Report X-2023110996
item.description:
Report X-2023110996

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-12T22:12:12+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-11-01
  • City: MEMPHIS
  • State: TN
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: ILLINOIS CENTRAL RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: A CN mechanical employee observed icing around the protective housing of tank car # UTLX 957945 along with a gas type odor while performing switching operations at the CN Harrison Yard in Memphis, TN. The CN Dangerous Goods Team was notified and responded to the rail yard to investigate. Upon arrival, the DGO observed a large ice buildup around the protective housing. Upon opening the housing, ice buildup was observed around the B end liquid valve. The valve was found to not be in the fully closed position with its securement plug less than tool tight (could turn by hand) allowing the tank cars contents to leak out. The liquid valve handle was hand tightened (approximately 1/4 turn) stopping the leak. The securement plug was removed, thread sealant applied, reinstalled and tightened with a pipe wrench. The railcar was released onto destination.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: The hazmat was found in the belly of trailer 824814 from Hartford during the preload. QA was notified and examined the package. The release from the hazmat was self contained and only affected the packaging of the hazmat itself. No release entered the trailer or contaminated other packages. The hazmat package was then removed from the trailer and brought to QA repack for processing. DescribePack: The cap on one of the bottles was loose causing roughly 2oz of the liquid to spill inside of the box. The face of the box closest to the spill became wet and ripped from the damage. It also became stained. The rip was at the top left of the face of the box. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: The package was removed and kept away from other boxes to prevent any potential additional spillage from causing damage. After DPR was processed caps were tightened on all bottles to prevent further spillage.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: The events that lead to the actual damage of the package are unknown, but once package was discovered immediate action was taken to isolate the package in the Hazmat processing cage, where it could be further looked over and investigated. DescribePack: Package contained four one gallon bottles of corrosive liquid. One bottle had a broken safety seal on the bottle, which caused it to leak out into the carton. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Once discovered, immediate action was taken to isolate the package in the Hazmat processing cage, away from the general area. Once inside the hazmat processing cage, the package was further looked over and processed thoroughly.

item.title: Report I-2023110075
item.description:
Report I-2023110075

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-12T22:12:12+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-10-18
  • City: MACON
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: JUBILANT RADIOPHARMA
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 1
  • Description: Vehicle 1 (tractor trailer) was westbound on 1-16 near mile marker 146, Vehicle 2 (Jubilant Radiopharma) was westbound on 1-16 near mile marker 146. Vehicle 1 was reentering the roadway from the right shoulder and vehicle 2 stuck the rear end of vehicle 1 at a speed of 71 mph. Both vehicles came to rest on the north shoulder facing west. Emergency response personnel arriving at the scene contacted CHEMTREC Emergency Services as vehicle 2 was carrying radioactive materials in Type A packaging. The Battalion Chief on the scene reported to CHEMTREC that he did not believe the load was compromised or releasing product. Battalion Chief then contacted the Radiation Safety Officer (RSO) from our Macon GA pharmacy to inform him of the accident. Jubilant Radiopharma RSO inform the Battalion Chief that all radioactive materials in the vehicle were well below limited quantity activity limits and there was no immediate danger to emergency personnel. Discussion between the Jubilant RSO, Battalion Chief and Georgia State Police regarding the radioactive material packages confirmed that all 6 packages were limited quantity shipments of radioactive material. All contents remained in the packages and all inner packaging's remained fully sealed and showed no damage. There was no release of any radioactive material to the environment.

DescribePack: UPON INSPECTION OF INNER CONTENTS DURING THE TWILIGHT SHIFT 4X1GALLON (PLASTIC BOTTLES) ZEP CALCIUM LIME & RUST SATIN REMOVER WITH LOOSE CAPS CAUSED LEAKAGING ALLOWING 10% SPILLAGE. WHICH ALSO CAUSED DAMAGE TO THE OUTER PACKAGING AS WELL. DurationRel: 8 and MitigateEffect: FACILITY PROCEDURES FOR DAMAGED HAZARDOUS MATERIAL FOLLOWED, CONTENTS CONTAINED AND AWAITING DISPOSITION.

  • Description: SequenceEvent: package was unloading from a trailer onto conveyor belt going to van line. it was noticed to be leaking. the package was then secured in a black FedEx container with a bag liner. When running lines, admin noticed the package, loaded it onto a tugger cart and brough it to QA for inspection. upon inspection, with gloves on, the package was continuously leaking. opening the box carefully and pulling the gallon plastic container out, it was noticed that one of the containers has been punctured with what looks like a small knife or nail. A DPR was submitted, and the package was put into a yellow hazmat bag lined salvage drum with packing securing the product in place. DescribePack: The fiberboard box was wet with product, the plastic container inside was punctured near the bottom on the container about the size of a small knife slit. DurationRel: 1 and MitigateEffect: Put it in a black tote the placed into yellow lined salvage drum after a DPR was submitted.

  • Description: Car TILX 310320 (residue propane) identified leaking in bowl track 27 by yard crew. The area was isolated and BNSF haz responders along with Graymar Env responded to assess the car. Crews found the plugs loose on the liquid line valves and vapor valve. Liquid propane was releasing through both liquid valves due to partially opened valves. The valves and plugs were secured and the car was released. All released product dissipated to atmosphere.

  • Description: On September 13, 2023, one (1) 330-gallon tote of UN3082 experienced a stress fracture and released approximately one (1) cup of product to the dock floor. R+L Carriers retained Cura Emergency Services, LC who dispatched a crew from Thin Line Environmental (TLE) to remediate the impacted site. The crew identified the damaged tote, patched the impacted area, and prepared for the gravity transfer. The crew labeled the new tote with the original labels and staged the drum onsite for handling by R+L personnel. The crew utilized absorbents to collect the released material. All waste was contained in one (1) 35-gallon drum.

item.title: Report I-2023100021
item.description:
Report I-2023100021

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-13T00:34:03+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-14
  • City: EAST POINT
  • State: GA
  • Report Type: Undeclared Shipment with no Release
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FEDEX TRADE NETWORKS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Location: FedEx Trade Networks Transport & Brokerage, Inc., 3700 Commerce Drive, East Point, GA 30344 08/29/23: Quality Importers Trading Company contacted our Miami branch office requesting a spot quote for two pallets from Miami, FL (MIA) to Erbil, Iraq (EBL) for non-hazardous materials cargo via air. 08/30/23: Quote# 20230830-457 was generated with non-hazardous rates. (See attached document) 09/05/23: Quality Importers approved the quote and sent our Miami office worker a Safety Data Sheet (SOS) for butane (see attached SDS). Our worker questioned the customer as they had previously stated no hazmat and that if there was, the quote would require updating. The customer responded that the lighters were empty. After that conversation, Southeastern Freight Lines was contracted to pick up the shipment at origin address and move to our warehouse in East Point, GA. This air freight shipment was planned to be shipped on Turkish Airlines (TK) via passenger aircraft. 09/11/23: Southeastern Freight Lines picked up the two pallets from the shipper's facility. (See attached BOL) 09/13/23: Upon arrival at our East Point, GA warehouse, our warehouse manager suspected that the shipment may contain hazardous materials based on a warehouse worker bringing attention to some odd markings on the shrink-wrapped skids. The warehouse manager pulled the commercial invoices and an SDS for butane off the shipment. On page 17 of the commercial invoice, butane is listed as being present in 12 cans at 8 ounces each. The odd markings are GHS labels reproduced on a paper sheet (see attached photographs). 09/14/23: Customer was contacted by our Miami office. Customer advises via email, "Yes, it contains butane cans. (Ten 12 pks of butane cans. Size 13.5 oz. per can) The lighters do not contain butane. They are empty. The commodities list for quote was not amended, sorry for that oversight as they were the last thing added to the order. " Our East Point warehouse engaged ProPack, a third party dangerous goods packer to identify the hazmat and repack. They discovered a box that was loaded on the pallet in such a manner that the pre-printed ground limited quantity mark was not viewable. Dry batteries under SP A123 were also discovered. I, Carla Andrews, Manager of Dangerous Goods/Safety was notified about an undeclared shipment. I immediately put the shipment on hold until further notice. Upon my review of the commercial invoice, I believed there were additional hazardous materials to potentially include lithium batteries. 09/15/23: I contacted the FAA as this shipment was scheduled to travel overseas by air. I spoke with Stan Satchell from the FAA about the shipment. Mr. Satchell informed me that FAA Safety Inspectors would arrive Monday, 09/17/23 to inspect the shipment. 09/18/23: At 1330 EDT, FAA Safety Inspectors Desmond Ruff and David Dixon arrived to inspect the shipment. They also discovered a maintenance kit that contained compressed air and butane. They did

item.title: Report X-2023101232
item.description:
Report X-2023101232

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-13T00:34:03+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-27
  • City: North Fond Du Lac
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: Wisconsin Central Railroad Ltd.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: On 2023-09-29 CN DGO was contacted via email by the Fond du Lac yardmaster, about a leaking tank car. During switching operations in the yard, the conductor smelled an odor as well noticed product leaking down the sides of tank car UTLX 201666 (L)UN3268 Class 3//(6.1)(8)//PG II. WASTE FLAMMABLE LIQUID, TOXIC, CORROSIVE, N.O.S. / (POTASSIUM HYDROXIDE ISOPROPANOL ORGANIC PESTICIDE). All CN departments were notified and the car was set out on NO61 for service and repair. I contacted a contractor to respond. Upon arrival and inspection of the car there was two of eight manway, securement bolts less then tool tight. After opening the manway there was found two gaskets one for the nozzle and another for the lid. The nozzle gasket was pinched and misaligned as the lid gasket was not of the correct size. Both gaskets were removed and the area cleaned. A new nozzle gasket was installed and the manway securement bolts were tightened tool tight. The car was cleaned of any residual product and released back to transportation to continue onto destination.

item.title: Report I-2023090165
item.description:
Report I-2023090165

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-13T00:34:03+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-08
  • City: ORLANDO
  • State: FL
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Air
  • Carrier/Reporter: FRONTIER AIRLINES HOLDINGS, INC.
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 0815 EDT the captain on inbound flight FFT1167 was taxing into gate 15 at Orlando International Airport (MCO) and called Ops and stated, "we have a fire". Ops notified the Comm Center and the airport fire department, which met the aircraft at the gate. We got the approval to pull the bridge up to the aircraft as it was advised the fire was out. The fire department entered the aircraft and determined it was safe to deplane the passengers. A woman, seated in row 7, tote bag began to smoke and catch on fire. The tote bag had a vape pen, a loose spare battery and a laptop in the tote bag. The flight attendants were quick to respond with a fire extinguisher and a fire containment bag and were able to put the fire out as fast as possible by using the fire containment bag to place the tote bag in it to stop the fire. The tote bag sustained heavy damage. Determined the tote bag contained a vape pen, a loose spare battery, and a laptop. Unsure if the vape pen or the loose battery began the thermal runaway as both were heavily damaged. The laptop was in the early stages of melting. There was no damage to the aircraft nor injured passengers on board. The fire department collected the fire containment bag with the tote bag in it. The passenger did eventually collect her laptop that was in the bag after speaking with the fire department and Frontier security.

item.title: Report X-2023091109
item.description:
Report X-2023091109

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-13T00:34:03+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-09-13
  • City: WATERLOO
  • State: IA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: CN RAILROAD
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: A CN Mechanical employee observed liquid dripping from the bottom outlet valve cap of tank car # CTCX 731039 while perform rail car inspections on an inbound train at the CN Waterloo Yard in Waterloo, IA. The employee notified the on duty transportation manager who in turn made all internal notifications to initiate a response to the incident. A CN Dangerous Goods Officer performed an inspection of the tank car and found the bottom outlet valve to be leaking from the threads of the bottom outlet valve cap as a result of the BOV not creating a proper seal and the BOV cap not tight enough to contain the leak. (The BOV cap was found to be tool tight and the BOV valve in the fully closed position upon initial inspection). The BOV valve handle was cycled several times to the open and closed position to free any debris that may have been trapped in the BOV sealing surface potentially causing the leak. The leak persisted after cycling the valve. A 24" pipe wrench was then used to turn the BOV operating stem in a counter clockwise direction in an attempt to further close the valve. The leak persisted after using the pipe wrench. A 36" pipe wrench was used to further tighten the BOV cap to stop the leak. Tightening the BOV cap further stopped the leak. (Approximately 1/4 turn). The BOV cap was loosened but not fully removed to observe the leakage volume during the above attempts to fully seat the valve. The tank car will be transloaded, cleaned and purged prior to being released for transportation. 09-20-2023 The tank car was transloaded into a shipper provided empty tank car. It was then cleaned and purged of all hazardous material. The BOV cap was removed so the gasket could be inspected. The gasket was found to be severely damaged and cut which ultimately contributed to the leak.

  • Description: Per report from United Alrlines Sr Manager Airport Ops (Olivia Boles), UA3612 YUL arrived to C109 at 18:39, while crew was downloading the flight, they noticed a bag was smoking. They moved it away from the aircraft and called ARFF and Police. Upon inspection they found melted wet swimwear in the bag along with an air tag in a plastic bag. Phone 732.306.0228, olivia.boles@united.com I have asked for a report and not received one. but the Deputy fire chief reported the following: "ARFF did respond and the call originated from the EWR PAPD desk. On arrival it was found that a bag had been damaged from heat or fire. Rescue 8 and Truck 4 responded which is typical outside of an alert dispatched by EANS. Upon investigation the ARFF crew found an Apple Air Tag overheating (tracking device) that also caused several wet bathing suits to melt in addition to the damaged bags. These tags have a lithium based battery and exposure to ater causes these thermal type events." I also reached out to the customer [REDACTED BY GEM/DATA OPS], who sent me pictures of the air tag (which was returned to her on site), it did not appear damaged and functioned normally. She also indicated the air tag was not on the side of the bag where the melteg hole was located. Phone [REDACTED BY GEM/DATA OPS]

item.description:
Report I-2023090148

Identified by scraper @ 2023-12-13T00:34:03+00:00

  • Incident Date: 2023-08-23
  • City: MILWAUKEE
  • State: WI
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident
  • Mode Of Transportation: Rail
  • Carrier/Reporter: SOO LINE RAILROAD COMPANY
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: At 10:00 on 8/23/2023 a SOO Line Railroad (DBA CPKC) Hazardous Materials Officer became aware that FRA Inspector Daniel Perkins had performed a hazmat Inspection at the CPKC Muskego yard in Milwaukee WI, and had cited loaded tank car UTLX 68278 (UN 3082, ENVIRONMENTALLY HAZARDOUS SUBSTANCE, LIQUID, N.O.S. (NONYLPHENOL), 9, PG Ill) for having a loose bottom outlet valve (BOV) plug, and for possibly leaking from around the BOV operating handle. A railroad qualified response contractor was mobilized to mitigate the release. Upon arrival, responders found the packing gland on the BOV handle was not tool tight, resulting in an appearance of "sweating" from around the packing gland on the BOV handle. Responders tightened the packing gland approximately 3/4 turn, stopping the leak. Responders also tightened the BOV secondary closure plug tool tight. The estimated trace release is 0.125 cup. Once the release was mitigated, the car was returned to transportation. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a 'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

  • Description: At 0525 on 8/23/23, the Kansas City Southern Railway's (OBA CPKCR) Jackson, MS rail yard reported tank car WCHX 29218 leaking from the top of the car. The Environmental & Hazmat Department mobilized a railroad qualified response contractor to mitigate the release. Upon arrival, responders found that the dome lid on WCHX 29218 was tool tight. The car was vented, and then the dome lid was opened. Responders found no manway gasket Installed. A new gasket was installed, and then the manway dome lid was closed and tightened tool tight Responders then remediated the spillage on top and sides of the rail car. No product was released on the ground. Estimated release was 3 gallons. Once secure, the car was released back Into transportation. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a 'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This carrier does not have access to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: The material on the trailer was collected from a Community Household Hazardous Waste collection event the same day as fire. Our driver heard a noise come from the trailer that he equated to a blown tire. He pulled to the shoulder of the road and noticed there was fire/flame coming from the trailer. He immediately unhooked the tractor from the trailer pulling ahead and called 911. He then called ERG owners and emergency assistance was contacted. ERG contacted Pros Services, a Hazardous Materials Response company to assist with clean up and remediation of the burned trailer and contents. ERG also contacted 911 towing to assist with the cleanup and removal of the trailer form the shoulder. During this time ERG was in constant communication with EGLE, DOT, local fire department and the state of Michigan about the fire. Estimated duration of the event was 8hrs. The trailer was taken off-site to 911 towing's yard. ERG/PRO's remediated the grass/soil under and around where the trailer was sitting during the final contents were a total loss. No injuries were sustained.

  • Description: At 09:00 on 8/31/2023 it was reported that the residue LPG tank car GATX 201163 was found to be leaking at the Kansas City Southern Railway (DBA CPKCR) Mossville yard in Westlake, LA. The Environmental & Hazmat Dept. mobilized a railroad qualified response contractor to mitigate the release. Upon arrival, responders found the vapor valve slightly open and lading leaking by the secondary closure plug, which was less than tool tight. The valve handle was zip tied, but the zip ties were not applied correctly to hold the valve in the closed position The zip ties were removed and the vapor valve handle was turned approximately ¼" inch to close the valve and stop the leak. The responders cleaned the secondary closure plug threads and applied clean Teflon tape before installing the secondary closure plug tool tight. All other closures were checked and found to be secure. Estimated release Is 0.5 gallons. After the tank car was secured, it was released back into transportation. File Note: Item 19-the quantity released was estimated based on the best information available at the time of filing. This shipment was offered as a 'bulk' shipment, aka one car load, therefore the exact amount offered in this package is not known to the carrier. This ss to mass balance data which can exactly quantify this value.

  • City: Escondido
  • State: CA
  • Report Type: A hazardous material incident

  • Carrier/Reporter: INGENIUM GROUP, LLC
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: Waste material was staged onto a pallet with other materials then loaded onto an lngenium truck at the customer's facility. The shipment was then routed through the lngenium - Santa Clara transfer facility, then to the lngenium - Escondido transfer facility. Upon arrival, lngenium - Escondido operations began unloading the shipment from the trailer with a forklift. The pallet with the container in question was picked up and the container was squeezed between the forklift mast and the pallet. The container sustained a minor gash near the bottom then leaked onto the trailer floor. The driver continued to unload the pallet when another employee noticed the leak. The forklift driver placed the pallet down and backed the forklift out of the trailer. The driver donned his respirator, grabbed absorbent pads, and began covering the release. The second employee notified the manager. The material was contained before spreading. The used absorbent was removed and, along with the damaged container, placed in a salvage drum for disposal.

FRA Inspection - 7/10/2023 - ID# H1606 - Report No. 109 Car - NDYX 130009 A field inspection was conducted at the Eastern Idaho Railroad yard in Jerome, ID on July 10, 2023. The inspection was conducted to verify compliance with 49 CFR regulation requirements concerning the proper shipment of hazardous materials in 24 marked and placard railroad shipments. Subject tank car described as UN1202, Loaded with Diesel Fuel, Flammable, was identified during inspection releasing product from the manway. After discovering the release, General Manager Scott Presley was contacted and alerted to the situation. It was determined there wasn't an active leak.

item.description:

  • City: JENKINTOWN

  • Mode Of Transportation: Highway
  • Carrier/Reporter: TruGreen
  • Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Hazmat Injuries: 0
  • Non-Hazmat Fatalities: 0
  • Description: According to the information obtained, the following occurred. While in transit, a TruGreen vehicle struck a guard pole at a fueling station. As a result of the impact, the hose connected to a vehicle-mounted, fiberglass tank was torn loose. The tank was carrying approximately 280 gallons of a solution of Fertilizer, Herbicide, Insecticide and Water, with water making up 98% of the solution. Approximately 280 gallons of free product was released to pavement and a storm drain at the loss location. Lewis Environmental was retained to perform the cleanup on site. The incident was reported to the National Response Center, the Pennsylvania Environmental Protection Agency, the Pennsylvania Emergency Management Agency, and the Montgomery County LEPC. No injuries or exposures were reported in connection with this incident.
